line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">A\ntypical US Soybean crushing system requires just over 20 litres of water per\ntonne of oil&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">produced\n</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">For each tonne of soybeans that go into the\nrefining process, 170 kg come out&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">as\ncrude de \u2013 gummed soybeans oil, 760 kg are soy meal ( which makes the HUMPLESS\nCOWS FART METHANE ) AND remaining 70 kg include air and solid and liquid waste</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The\nprimary contaminant in wastewater is soybean oil . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Production\nof ethanol, in particular, requires a tremendous amount of water for processing&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">and\nfor evaporative cooling to keep fermentation temperatures at the required level\n.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">But&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">some\nfeed stocks are more water intensive than other; each tonne of sugar cane in\nBrazil, for&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">example,\nrequires as much as 4050 litres WATER for processing .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ethanol processing also\nresults&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">in\nlarge volumes of nutrient rich wastewater that, if not cleaned and recycled can\nspeed&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">eutrophication\nof local rivers and streams by affecting the water\u2019s dissolved oxygen content</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Sugar\nmills must be flushed every year, putting huge amount of organic<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">matter\ninto local waterways . One litre of ethanol produces more than 16 litres of<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">vinasse\nwhich is very hot and corrosive, with a low acidic pH and high mineral content .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Vinasse\ncannot be used where water tables are high, such as in India. Also, if used\nexcessively, &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">vinasse\ncan cause eutrophication of surface water due to the increased load.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Among\nthe pollutant that bio refineries emit in to the air are SOx, NOX, VOCs and<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">particulate\nmatter. Emission from corn ethanol plants, for example include SOx, NOx, CO,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">mercury,\nparticulates and CO . &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">Corn ethanol plants pollute air, emitting cancer causing\nchemicals such as formaldehyde and toluene .</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Biodiesel\nproduction require methanol, which has the same environmental cost as those&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">associated\nwith petroleum production. In addition, direct emission from biodiesel&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">processing\nplants can include hexane, which can be used to extract oil from&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">plants\nand seeds.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">The average&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">US\nsoybean crushing system releases just more than 13 Kg of hexane per tonne of\noil produced.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Alternatives\nhave been found so that hexane is no longer needed; but these options are costly\n. In addition, where renewable sources are not used to produce process energy,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">pollutants\nassociated with the use for natural gas and the generation of steam and\nelectricity&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">are\nreleased into air.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">An estimated 4.05 Kilowatt hours of electricity are required\nper ton of&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">soybeans\nentering in a soy biodiesel plant. With ethanol fuel combustion, emission of\nthe toxic air pollutants acetaldehyde,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">formaldehyde,\nperoxyacetyl nitrate (PAN) increase relative to straight gasoline.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Aldehydes\nmight be carcinogenic; but the pollutant that are reduced by<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">blending\nwith ethanol (including benzene, 1,3 \u2013 butadiene, toluene and xylene) are&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">considered\nmore dangerous for human health. Ethanol and biodiesel emit higher amounts of\nnitrogen oxides&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">(NOx)\nthan</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\">conventional fuels.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">Ozone\nlevels &nbsp;FELL drastically in the Brazilian\ncity of Sao Paulo when drivers switched from burning ethanol to gasoline in\nresponse to higher ethanol prices. In Brazil\u2019s largest city, nearly a half of\nlight vehicles have flex-fuel capability meaning that they can switch between\nburning gasoline or ethanol or some combination of the two.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">WE\nWILL NOT ALLOW GM FOOD LOBBERMAAN MODI TO DECIMATE INDIAs FERTILE AND HOLY TOP\nSOIL BY SUCKING UP TO ZIONIST JEW GM COMPANIES LIKE MONSANTO.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">BHAAD MEIN\nGAYE MODI KA NOBEL PRIZE , AT THE EXPENSE OF THE WATAN &nbsp;!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sea water scrubbing has\nfound application in coal and oil-fired power plants.&nbsp; However, this process is suitable only for\nplants in the coastal area.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Due to its natural\nalkalinity, seawater can absorb acidic gases. In this process, flue gases flow\ncounter current to seawater in an absorption tower. The sea water gets heated\nand the flue gas is cooled. SO2 in the flue gases is absorbed by the sea water\nand then passes to a water treatment plant where further seawater is added to\nincrease the pH.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Air is supplied to oxidize the SO2 to sulphite and to saturate\nthe seawater with oxygen. This system can remove up to 99% SO2<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wet scrubbing systems\nare typically used for flue gas desulfurisation. After leaving the dust removal\nplant, the flue gas enters a tower where it is sprayed with a calcium-based\nslurry (scrubbing liquid, eg, ground limestone in water) that is fed from a\ntank.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The gaseous pollutants such as SO2 are dissolved in the liquid and react\nwith the liquid to form calcium sulfite or sulfate, which is removed by\ndewatering and settling into a thickener. Alternatively, calcium sulfite is\noxidised to form gypsum by bubbling compressed air through the sulfite slurry.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GrPjL8aT1HE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GrPjL8aT1HE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vy7OyGSOpE8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/vy7OyGSOpE8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mercury is a highly\ntoxic element commonly found in coal and municipal waste. Wet scrubbers are\nonly effective for removal of soluble mercury species, such as oxidized\nmercury, Hg2+. Mercury vapor in its elemental form, Hg0, is insoluble in the\nscrubber slurry and not removed.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GxHQHcpCWa8/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/GxHQHcpCWa8?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Therefore, additional process of Hg0\nconversion is required to complete mercury capture. Usually addition of the\nhalogens to the flue gas are used for this purpose.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/AyAd-gLO9CE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/AyAd-gLO9CE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The type of coal burned as\nwell as the presence of a selective catalytic reduction unit both affect the\nratio of elemental to oxidized mercury in the flue gas and thus the degree to\nwhich the mercury is removed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mercury scrubbers\ninstalled on coal power plants capture PAH (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons)\nemissions as well.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Cw9x4tgeEIc/VnK_Y03_pzI/AAAAAAABCyQ/ICOxFVvj8vM/s1600/Mercury-overvwiew-figure.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"384\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-Cw9x4tgeEIc/VnK_Y03_pzI/AAAAAAABCyQ/ICOxFVvj8vM/s640/Mercury-overvwiew-figure.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fossil fuels such as\ncoal and oil contain a significant amount of sulfur. When fossil fuels are\nburned, about 95 percent or more of the sulfur is generally converted to sulfur\ndioxide (SO2).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Such conversion happens under normal conditions of temperature\nand of oxygen present in the flue gas. However, there are circumstances, under\nwhich such reaction may not occur.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">When flue gas has too\nmuch oxygen, the SO2 further oxidizes into sulfur trioxide (SO3). Too much\noxygen is only one of the ways that SO3 is formed. Gas temperature is also an\nimportant factor. At about 800 \u00b0C, formation of SO3 is favored.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another way\nthat SO3 can be formed is through catalysis by metals in the fuel. Such\nreaction is particularly true for heavy fuel oil, where a significant amount of\nvanadium is present. In whatever way SO3 is formed, it does not behave like SO2\nin that it forms a liquid aerosol known as sulfuric acid (H2SO4) mist that is\nvery difficult to remove.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Generally, about 1% of the sulfur dioxide will be\nconverted to SO3. Sulfuric acid mist is often the cause of the blue haze that\noften appears as the flue gas plume dissipates. Increasingly, this problem is\nbeing addressed by the use of wet electrostatic precipitators.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In wet scrubbing\nsystems, the flue gas normally passes first through a fly ash removal device,\neither an electrostatic precipitator or a wet scrubber, and then into the\nSO2-absorber. However, in dry injection or spray drying operations, the SO2 is\nfirst reacted with the sorbent, and then the flue gas passes through a\nparticulate control device.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another important\ndesign consideration associated with wet FGD systems is that the flue gas\nexiting the absorber is saturated with water and still contains some SO2. These\ngases are highly corrosive to any downstream equipment such as fans, ducts, and\nstacks.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Two methods that may minimize corrosion are: (1) reheating the gases to\nabove their dew point, or (2) using materials of construction and designs that\nallow equipment to withstand the corrosive conditions. Both alternatives are\nexpensive. Engineers determine which method to use on a site-by-site basis.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A venturi scrubber is a\nconverging/diverging section of duct. The converging section accelerates the\ngas stream to high velocity. When the liquid stream is injected at the throat,\nwhich is the point of maximum velocity, the turbulence caused by the high gas\nvelocity atomizes the liquid into small droplets, which creates the surface\narea necessary for mass transfer to take place.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The higher the pressure drop in\nthe venturi, the smaller the droplets and the higher the surface area. The\npenalty is in power consumption.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For simultaneous\nremoval of SO2 and fly ash, venturi scrubbers can be used. In fact, many of the\nindustrial sodium-based throwaway systems are venturi scrubbers originally\ndesigned to remove particulate matter.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These units were slightly modified to\ninject a sodium-based scrubbing liquor. Although removal of both particles and\nSO2 in one vessel can be economic, the problems of high pressure drops and\nfinding a scrubbing medium to remove heavy loadings of fly ash must be\nconsidered.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, in cases where the particle concentration is low, such as\nfrom oil-fired units, it can be more effective to remove particulate and SO2\nsimultaneously.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Alkaline sorbents are\nused for scrubbing flue gases to remove SO2. Depending on the application, the\ntwo most important are lime and sodium hydroxide (also known as caustic soda).\nLime is typically used on large coal- or oil-fired boilers as found in power\nplants, as it is very much less expensive than caustic soda.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem is\nthat it results in a slurry being circulated through the scrubber instead of a\nsolution. This makes it harder on the equipment. A spray tower is typically\nused for this application. The use of lime results in a slurry of calcium\nsulfite (CaSO3) that must be disposed of.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Fortunately, calcium sulfite can be\noxidized to produce by-product gypsum (CaSO4 \u2022 2H2O) which is marketable for\nuse in the building products industry.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Caustic soda is limited\nto smaller combustion units because it is more expensive than lime, but it has\nthe advantage that it forms a solution rather than a slurry. This makes it\neasier to operate.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It produces a \"spent caustic\" solution of sodium\nsulfite/bisulfite (depending on the pH), or sodium sulfate that must be\ndisposed of. This is not a problem in a kraft pulp mill for example, where this\ncan be a source of makeup chemicals to the recovery cycle.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It is possible to scrub\nsulfur dioxide by using a cold solution of sodium sulfite, this forms a sodium\nhydrogen sulfite solution. By heating this solution it is possible to reverse\nthe reaction to form sulfur dioxide and the sodium sulfite solution. Since the\nsodium sulfite solution is not consumed, it is called a regenerative treatment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The highest SO2 removal\nefficiencies (greater than 90%) are achieved by wet scrubbers and the lowest\n(less than 80%) by dry scrubbers. However, the newer designs for dry scrubbers\nare capable of achieving efficiencies in the order of 90%.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In spray drying and dry\ninjection systems, the flue gas must first be cooled to about 10\u201320 \u00b0C above\nadiabatic saturation to avoid wet solids deposition on downstream equipment and\nplugging of baghouses.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pxiRC44tN70/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/pxiRC44tN70?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The recently developed\nbiological alternative Thiopaq combines gas purification with sulfur recovery.\nMicro-organisms in a bioreactor oxidise the sulfide to elemental sulfur. This\nelemental S is then separated and finally recovered at the end of the process\nfor further usage in, for example, agricultural products.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Safety is one of the\ngreatest benefits of this method, as the whole process takes place at\natmospheric pressure and ambient temperature<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/rpFyIYpfVg4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/rpFyIYpfVg4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cyclones are &nbsp;efficient for the coarse fraction but have\nminor effect on the submicron particles. The main application for cyclones in\nmodern biomass plants&nbsp; is as\nprecollectors. A special application is the cyclones at about 900 \u00b0C in&nbsp; circulating fluidized bed boilers (CFBC:s).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/AsKc52gHq9E/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/AsKc52gHq9E?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/x5YFK8mmeRQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/x5YFK8mmeRQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/v4DPLy6haOE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/v4DPLy6haOE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/AcyFY3iAdlw/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/AcyFY3iAdlw?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/X3qkRs_x9Zk/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/X3qkRs_x9Zk?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/6AkTNNqwtaE/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/6AkTNNqwtaE?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/IiRyxcCBTa0/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/IiRyxcCBTa0?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wet scrubbers with condensation\n(CWS) are installed mainly for energy recovery and are then often just called\nthe condensation unit.&nbsp; The cold surfaces\nfor the condensation are either cold droplets in a scrubber, cold surfaces in a\nheat exchanger or a combination. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Condensation, like\nelectrical forces, improves the removal of submicron particles. A well, also\nfor removal of particles, designed condensation unit has a dust removal\nefficiency between low- and high pressure drop scrubbers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wet electrostatic\nprecipitators (WESP) Wet electrostatic precipitators (WESP) are very effective\nparticle separators. They are not dependent on the dust resistivity, as are\nDESP, as the dust is flushed off, more or less continuously, from the\ncollecting plates.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For the same reason, there is no reentrainment of collected\ndust. The WESP can be designed for a very high dust removal.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When low temperature\nheat is to be recovered by condensation the combination of a condenser and a\nwet electrostatic precipitator is often a good solution at least for small and\nmedium size boilers.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The WESP is very effective in removing submicron particles\nindependently of the dust composition. Recollection of thecoarse dust in e.g.\ncyclones is normally necessary. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">WESP is also useful incombination\nwith wet scrubbers for gaseous impurities.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Typical water soluble\ngases from biomass boilers are:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Sulphur dioxide (SO2)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Hydrochloric acid\n(HCl)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Hydrofluoric acid\n(HF) and<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2022 Ammonia (NH3)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Scrubbers are one of\nthe primary devices that control gaseous emissions, especially acid gases.\nScrubbers can also be used for heat recovery from hot gases by flue-gas\ncondensation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wet scrubbing works via\nthe contact of target compounds or particulate matter with the scrubbing\nsolution<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Process exhaust gas can\nalso contain water-soluble toxic and/or corrosive gases like hydrochloric acid\n(HCl) or ammonia (NH3). These can be removed very well by a wet scrubber.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Removal efficiency of\npollutants is improved by increasing residence time in the scrubber or by the\nincrease of surface area of the scrubber solution by the use of a spray nozzle,\npacked towers or an aspirator. Wet scrubbers may increase the proportion of\nwater in the gas, resulting in a visible stack plume, if the gas is sent to a\nstack.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Wet scrubbers can also\nbe used for heat recovery from hot gases by flue-gas condensation. In this\nmode, termed a condensing scrubber, water from the scrubber drain is circulated\nthrough a cooler to the nozzles at the top of the scrubber.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The hot gas enters\nthe scrubber at the bottom. If the gas temperature is above the water dew\npoint, it is initially cooled by evaporation of water drops. Further cooling\ncause water vapors to condense, adding to the amount of circulating water.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The gas leaves the\nscrubber at its dew point, so even though significant amounts of water may have\nbeen removed from the cooled gas, it is likely to leave a visible stack plume\nof water vapor.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dry scrubbers generally\ndo not have a stack steam plume or wastewater handling/disposal requirements.\nDry scrubbing systems are used to remove acid gases (such as SO2 and HCl)\nprimarily from combustion sources.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dry scrubbing systems\ncan be categorized as dry sorbent injectors (DSIs) or as spray dryer absorbers\n(SDAs). Spray dryer absorbers are also called semi-dry scrubbers or spray\ndryers.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dry scrubbing systems\nare often used for the removal of odorous and corrosive gases from wastewater\ntreatment plant operations. The medium used is typically an activated alumina\ncompound impregnated with materials to handle specific gases such as hydrogen sulfide.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Media used can be mixed together to offer a wide range of removal for other\nodorous compounds such as methyl mercaptans, aldehydes, volatile organic\ncompounds, dimethyl sulfide, and dimethyl disulfide.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dry sorbent injection\ninvolves the addition of an alkaline material (usually hydrated lime, soda ash,\nor sodium bicarbonate) into the gas stream to react with the acid gases. The\nsorbent can be injected directly into several different locations: the\ncombustion process, the flue gas duct (ahead of the particulate control\ndevice), or an open reaction chamber (if one exists).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The acid gases react with\nthe alkaline sorbents to form solid salts which are removed in the particulate\ncontrol device. These simple systems can achieve only limited acid gas (SO2 and\nHCl) removal efficiencies.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Higher collection efficiencies can be achieved by\nincreasing the flue gas humidity (i.e., cooling using water spray). These\ndevices have been used on medical waste incinerators and a few municipal waste\ncombustors.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In spray dryer\nabsorbers, the flue gases are introduced into an absorbing tower (dryer) where\nthe gases are contacted with a finely atomized alkaline slurry. Acid gases are\nabsorbed by the slurry mixture and react to form solid salts which are removed\nby the particulate control device.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The heat of the flue gas is used to\nevaporate all the water droplets, leaving a non-saturated flue gas to exit the\nabsorber tower. Spray dryers are capable of achieving high (80+%) acid gas\nremoval efficiencies. These devices have been used on industrial and utility\nboilers and municipal waste incinerators.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Poorly maintained\nscrubbers have the potential to spread disease-causing bacteria.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"comment-header\" id=\"bc_0_103M\" kind=\"m\" style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: 'Times New Roman', Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.4px; margin: 0px 0px 8px;\">\n<cite class=\"user blog-author\" style=\"font-style: normal; font-weight: bold;\"><a href=\"https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration: none;\">Capt. Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; Ajit Vadakayil</a></cite><span class=\"icon user blog-author\" style=\"background-image: url(&quot;data:image/png; background-repeat: no-repeat; display: inline-block; font-weight: bold; height: 18px; margin: 0px 0px -4px 6px; width: 18px;\"></span><span class=\"datetime secondary-text\" style=\"margin-left: 6px;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2017/12/steroid-pumped-muscles-do-not-provide.html?showComment=1513752175650#c2461307375127586492\" rel=\"nofollow\" style=\"color: #888888; text-decoration-line: none;\">December 20, 2017 at 12:12 PM</a></span></div>\n<div class=\"comment-content\" id=\"bc_0_56MC\" style=\"font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;, Times, FreeSerif, serif; font-size: 16px; margin-bottom: 8px; text-align: justify;\">\n<span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/12/thermal-coal-power-plants-clean-exhaust_9.html</span><br /><br />I HAVE WRITTEN ABOUT COAL GASIFICATION TWO YEARS AGO ( IN MY 6 PARTS SERIES ABOVE ) FOR SYNGAS PRODUCTION AND FURTHER METHANOL SYNTHESIS<br /><br />THEY HAVE LIFTED FROM MY POSTS.<br /><br />Coal gasification, followed by the water shift reaction, can be used to produce syngas which is then converted downstream to methanol.<br /><br />ROTHSCHILD STARTED PRODUCING COAL FROM RANIGANJ COALFIELD USING HIS OPIUM DRUG RUNNING AGENT AND SONAGACHI WHORE HOUSE OWNER DWARAKNATH TAGORE (GRANDFATHER OF RABINDRANATH TAGORE ) .<br /><br />DWARAKNATH TAGORE USED TRIBALS SANTALS AND BAURIS AS SLAVES IN COALMINES<br /><br />RANIGANJ COAL IS SUITABLE FOR COAL GASIFICATION<br /><br />Methane aDdsorbed into the solid matrix of the coal is called 'sweet gas' because of its lack of hydrogen sulfide. Methane is stored within the coal by a process called aDsorption.<br /><br />The methane is in a near-liquid state, lining the inside of pores within the coal (called the matrix). The open fractures in the coal (called the cleats) can also contain free gas or can be saturated with water.<br /><br />UCG ( UNDERGROUND COAL GASIFICATION without fracking ) delivers 20 times more energy from the same coal resource than what\u2019s possible from CSG (COAL SEAM GAS )<br /><br />Air or a combination of oxygen and steam are injected into the&nbsp;gasification panel within the coal seam. The coal is then heated and controlled reactions convert solid coal into product gas, known as SYNGAS, which is extracted at the surface<br /><br />Underground coal gasification (UCG) is extraction of energy from coal and lignite resources that are otherwise deemed uneconomical through conventional mining methods.<br /><br />UCG technology protects natural groundwater reserves. Groundwater quality is preserved by operating the gasification process below the hydrostatic pressure<br /><br />Maintaining the surrounding groundwater pressure acts as containment for the gasification process and ensures that the product gas, \u201csyngas\u201d, flows to the surface under pressure via the Production Well.<br /><br />The mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen is called synthesis gas or SYNGAS.<br /><br />IDIOTS IN THE COAL MINISTRY DO NOT KNOW ALL THIS<br /><br />In the Surat Basin, the CSG process extracts HUMONGOUS QUANTITIES OF GROUND WATER for every PJ of gas.<br /><br />CSG recovers gas out of the coal seam without utilising the energy in the coal itself.<br /><br />Following CSG production the energy contained within the coal itself cannot be harnessed using UCG technology until natural groundwater pressure is restored.<br /><br />The Fischer-Tropsch (FT) process, is a series of chemical reactions that involve the conversion of hydrogen and carbon monoxide into liquid hydrocarbons by using a catalyst. Nickel is used as the catalyst, as it tends to promote methane formation.<br /><br /><span style=\"color: red;\">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=44OU4JxEK4k<br /><br />https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0mn8xpSqUho</span><br /><br />Mathanol is periodically used as a replacement for gasoline, particularly for racing fuel, as it has a high octane number. It has no sulfur in it, will produce almost no NOX due to the low flame temperature, and can be blended with gasoline.<br /><br />ON CHEMICAL TANKERS WE ARE EXPERTS IN METHANOL<br /><br />THE POSTS BELOW SHOWS THAT SEA IS A PLACE FOR CUNTS<br /><br /><span style=\"color: red;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2010/11/methanol-spray-on-chemical-tankers-capt.html<br /><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2011/01/airline-breathing-apparatus-on-chemical.html<br /><br />http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2012/07/my-experience-at-mundra-port-adani-sez.html</span><br /><br />capt ajit vadakayil<br />..</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: left;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<b><span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-size: large;\">THIS POST IS CONTINUED TO PART 6 BELOW-</span></b></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/12/thermal-coal-power-plants-clean-exhaust_18.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.in/2015/12/thermal-coal-power-plants-clean-exhaust_18.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n<br /></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JWoE-lO7LSo/VnDBj03x75I/AAAAAAABCwE/0qdakMpE1IM/s1600/20151129_210135.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-JWoE-lO7LSo/VnDBj03x75I/AAAAAAABCwE/0qdakMpE1IM/s320/20151129_210135.jpg\" width=\"147\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\nCAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n..</div>\n</div>\n", "author": {"id": "14410812789424637654", "displayName": "Capt. Ajit Vadakayil", "url": "https://www.blogger.com/profile/14410812789424637654", "image": {"url": "//4.bp.blogspot.com/-QSnd-Z8F7Kc/XFtPudWdwlI/AAAAAAABfq4/vxrkFOO7Iu8Mf6-OaPgw6FPpRDSmMgLdgCK4BGAYYCw/s35/capt%25252BajitC%25252Bvadakayil.JPG"}}, "replies": {"totalItems": "203", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/7622491018549789026/comments"}}, {"kind": "blogger#post", "id": "5609508341300050544", "blog": {"id": "3564735312144269387"}, "published": "2015-12-12T06:07:00+05:30", "updated": "2015-12-20T14:35:48+05:30", "etag": "\"iHf3yWDE_geBgZ8U7rgZ_xuTeAQ/dGltZXN0YW1wOiAxNDUwNjAyMzQ4Nzc5Cm9mZnNldDogMTk4MDAwMDAK\"", "url": "http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2015/12/thermal-coal-power-plants-clean-exhaust_12.html", "selfLink": "https://www.googleapis.com/blogger/v3/blogs/3564735312144269387/posts/5609508341300050544", "title": "THERMAL COAL POWER PLANTS , CLEAN EXHAUST FLUE GAS EMISSIONS, PART 4 - CAPT AJIT VADAKAYIL", "content": "<div dir=\"ltr\" style=\"text-align: left;\" trbidi=\"on\">\n<span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></span>\n<span style=\"font-size: large;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\">THIS POST IS A CONTINUANCE OF THE POST BELOW--</b></span><br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/msreNyb1mYQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/msreNyb1mYQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">Methane\n&nbsp;is a chemical compound with the chemical\nformula CH4 (one atom of carbon and four atoms of hydrogen).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">It is the simplest\nalkane and the main component of natural gas. In its natural state, methane is\nfound both below ground and under the sea floor, where it often finds its way\nto the surface and the atmosphere where it is known as atmospheric methane.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">Methane\nin the form of compressed natural gas is used as a vehicle fuel.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">Liquefied natural gas (LNG) is natural gas\n(predominantly methane, CH4) that has been converted to liquid form for ease of\nstorage or transport.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">The NANO\nCARBON emissions breach the blood brain barrier and is responsible for women\u2019s\nblighted pregnancies.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\">Liquefied\nnatural gas takes up about 1/600th the volume of natural gas in the gaseous\nstate. Methane &nbsp;degrades on of the ozone\nlayer.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-_9E9U0KEKks/VmubQNVerkI/AAAAAAABCpk/oLGGAeLbAvc/s1600/methanFFe.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; font-family: &quot;cambria&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: x-large; line-height: 200%; mso-ascii-theme-font: major-latin; mso-bidi-font-family: &quot;Times New Roman&quot;; mso-hansi-theme-font: major-latin;\"><b>FUCK THE FRACKERS !</b></span><br />\n<span style=\"color: red; THIS IS NOT WRITTEN ANYWHERE TILL TODAY&nbsp;</b><br />\n<b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both;
